The Prime Minister said that over the coming months various times of Ministers would need to be in attendance at Standing CommitteesMeeting. of the House of Commons which sat on Tuesday and Thursdaymorning, and he had been wondering whether it would not be con-venient on this account to revert to the pre-war practice of holdingone regular weekly meeting of the Cabinet on Wednesday morning.Additional meetings could be held, if required, on Monday orThursday afternoon.In discussion it was pointed out that the Scottish Grand Com-mittee of the House of Commons met on Wednesdays and that, whenbusiness became congested, the other Standing Committees might need to meet on three mornings of the week, including Wednesday.For the time being, however, the balance of advantage lay on the sideof holding the main Cabinet meeting on Wednesday morning.The Cabinet Agreed that during the next few weeks they would aim attransacting their weekly business at a regular meeting onWednesday morning, but invited Ministers to hold them-selves free to attend an additional meeting, if required, onMonday at 4 - 30 p.m.Five-Power 3. The Prime Minister drew attention to a telegram from theMeeting. Foreign Secretary (Berlin telegram No. 12 of 25th January) suggesting that the United Kingdom Government should review their attitudetowards the proposal for a Five-Power Meeting on the problems ofthe Far East. It was clear that this proposal would be strongly pressed at the Berlin Meeting, and that the French would be embarrassed if their Western allies adopted a wholly unconstruetiveattitude towards it. The Foreign Secretary was now inclined to thinkthat it might be wise to accept the proposal, if the Americans couldbe persuaded to agree to it.The Prime Minister said that, if there was no prospect of making progress on Far Eastern questions either at Panmunjom or in theUnited Nations, it would be unreasonable to resist a proposal thatthese questions should be discussed at a Five-Power Meeting convenedfor that purpose. He hoped that the Foreign Secretary might be ableto bring the Americans round to this opinion.In discussion there was general agreement with the PrimeMinister^ view.The Cabinet-Took note that the Prime Minister would inform the foreign secretary that they were in full sympathy with his view thatit would be inexpedient to resist a proposal for a Five-power meeting confined to Far Eastern questions and beginning with Korea, and hoped that he might be able to persuade the United States Secretary of State to fall in with this view.Parliament. 1. The Cabinet were informed of the business which it was" " hoped to take in the House of Commons in the; following week.Progress would be made with some of the less controversial Bills inthe Governments legislative programme. (54) 2ndConclusions,Minute 6.)Defence Policy.6. The Cabinet had before them a memorandum by the Ministerof Defence (C. (54) 26) seeking approval of the plan of re-deployment of British forces in the Middle East which had been outlined in theAppendix to C. (54) 9.The Minister of Defence said that a re-deployment plan wouldbe needed, whether we concluded a defence agreement with Egypt,or whether we decided to abandon negotiations and withdraw our forces in our own time. Under the plan recommended by the Chiefsof Staff we should, station an armoured brigade group less one armoured regiment in Libya, one armoured squadron possibly in-creased subsequently to one armoured regiment-in Jordan, and the headquarters of an armoured division and an infantry brigade groupwith some divisional troops in Cyprus. The Middle East air forces would be distributed between Habbaniya, Jordan, Cyprus and Aden.Once this re-deployment had been carried out, one division and oneparachute brigade would be free to return to the United kingdom to form a strategic reserve. It would be helpful if this plan couldbe approved now, though it would be clearly understood that it couldnot be put into operation without a further Cabinet decision.The Secretary of State for War said that he hoped the cabinet would also approve a maximum establishment of 2,500 for the joint Headquarters in Cyprus, so that the works programme in Cypruscould go forward.In connexion with these proposals the Minister of Defence saidthat he was also considering the possibility that, if it were decidedto withdraw the British forces from the Canal Zone, the Middle EastHeadquarters would be moved to Cyprus in the early stages of thewithdrawal. This would be specially desirable if Anglo-Egyptianrelations deteriorated and serious disturbances were expected to takeplace in the Canal Zone. In reply to points made in this part of thediscussion, the Minister said that such a movement would have tobe so presented as to avoid any impression that the withdrawal wasbeing forced on us by the Egyptians. The move would not in any event take place until after the Government had announced their future policy for the defence of the Middle East.The Cabinet (1) Approved the re-deployment plan proposed by the Chiefs ofStaff, as set out in the Appendix to C. (54) 9, on the under-standing that no troops would be moved in accordancewith the plan without further reference to the Cabinet.(2) Approved a maximum establishment of 2,500 for the jointHeadquarters in Cyprus.7. The Cabinet had before them a memorandum by thePresident of the Board of Trade (C. (54) 24) summarising thearguments for and against issuing invitations to the Chinese to visit the British Industries Fair in May, 1954.In a preliminary discussion the view was expressed that littlepractical advantage would be gained by the attendance of Chinesevisitors at the Fair. Their main interest would be in strategic materials which were subject to embargo. Moreover, the issue ofinvitations to the Chinese would provoke unfavourable comment inthe United States and might prejudice our chance of persuading theUnited States Government to adopt a more liberal policy towardstrade with the Soviet bloc.The Cabinet Agreed to resume discussion of C. (54) 24 at their next meeting, when the President of the Board of Trade would be present.8. The Parliamentary Secretary, Ministry of Labour, said thatthere was a threat of a strike among the employees of municipal and private bus companies outside London. The municipal busmen hadbeen given an award of 4^. at arbitration, but the private companies had not so far gone to arbitration. In view of the award of 75. toLondon busmen and the similar offer which was likely to be made tothe railwaymen, it seemed certain that, unless something nearer 7s.were offered to the municipal and private busmen, there would be astrike. He was seeing both sides that day and he might be able to persuade them to reach a settlement. He hoped that it would not benecessary to appoint a court of enquiry, since this was a course whichwas best kept in reserve for more important disputes.
